awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Optimal time scales for integrating paleoecological and fossil data in human evolutionary studies
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). 

Humans have a unique suite of biological adaptations, many of which can be observed at various points in the primate and human evolutionary fossil record. To investigate how and why these adaptations occurred, it is critical that scientists consider not only the fossils themselves but their ecological and environmental contexts. This doctoral dissertation project addresses important questions about the optimal time scale(s) for investigating links between early humans and their environments. The investigators use data from high-resolution geological sediments to reconstruct and analyze environmental change at various scales of observation and consider how different patterns emerge depending on scale. The project also includes opportunities for student training and mentoring, public science outreach activities, and strengthening of international research collaborations.

Interpretations of large- and small-scale paleoecological trends are developed to assess how scale may influence interpretations of mammalian dietary ecology, as well as early human environments within a relatively continuous geologic sequence where fossil apes and humans have been recovered. The investigators develop long-term, coarsely resolved dietary data for 8 herbivore lineages for periods from 13-8.5 Ma and 5.3-1.6 Ma. They develop temporally refined, short-term dietary data for herbivores from 4-2 Ma. Each fossil sample is correlated to a specific geologic horizon— and subsequently a specific date—for which detailed paleoclimatic and paleobotanical data have been published. The project enables the diets of individual animals to be reconstructed to the level of vegetation type and then be compared to outstanding paleoclimatic datasets in order to better understand prevailing modes of paleoecological change in the region. These data can advance the integration of paleoecological patterns at various temporal scales to help clarify the types of environmentally-selective forces experienced by the hominin and hominoid lineages.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Understanding the evolutionary environments that early apes and humans lived in is critical for supporting hypotheses relating to their paleobiology and life histories, as evolutionary milestones such as obligate bipedalism, increased brain size, tool creation, and language are all intricately linked to environmental contexts. However reconstructing these environments is often difficult due to poor preservation of fossil material, as well as the averaging of fossil material in time and space. In order to better support palaeobiological hypotheses concerning hominoid and hominin evolution it is important to better refine and understand how ‘scaling’ influences our analyses of paleoenvironmental change through time, and how we use it to extrapolate the relationships between organismal adaptation to physical environments.

This project analyzed fossil material from the Tugen Hills Succession (THS) (Figure 1) of the Baringo Basin (Kenya), which is a nearly continuous geologic succession spanning from the middle Miocene (~15.5 Ma) to the late Pleistocene (~240 ka) that has yielded an extensive faunal record, including one of the largest concentrations of hominoids from 14 to 4 Ma, as well as several hominin specimens from ~6 to 0.2 Ma. During the THS, C4 (monocot) grassland expansion is hypothesized to have influenced hominin expansion into open habitats during the Plio-Pleistocene, however recent work suggests that while evidence for C4 biomass in eastern African ecosystems occurs as early as 21 Ma, C4 grazing herbivore guilds did not become well established until the late Miocene. Herbivore lineages, especially Equidae, began exploiting C4 vegetation after immigrating to Africa ~10 Ma, but it remains unclear (1) how other mammalian guilds incorporated such dietary resources at this time, and (2) how C4-mediated dietary change occurred between different eastern African localities from the Miocene to the Plio-Pleistocene. The relative continuity of fossiliferous sediments in the THS provides a unique context for documenting mammalian response to environmental change through its 15.5 Ma history and provides an opportunity for developing a framework to explore the ecological effects of large-scale temporal changes in hominoid and hominin environments.

So far, THS data has established that an opening up of C4 environments occurred in the basin after 10 Ma, with earlier ape sites from 12.5-12.3 Ma representative of closed rainforest to wet/dry woodland environments. Faunal communities seem to broadly track his change, with forest-adapted bovids and suids (pigs) going extinct after 10 Ma, and Equidae (horses) moving into the African continent shortly after 10 Ma. More research is needed in this interval, however, because it is still unclear how and why some groups went extinct while others immigrated in to eastern Africa. Ideally, site-specific analyses following the stable carbon isotopic signatures of mammalian communities in conjunction with microwear analyses (which track microscopic abrasion of the tooth surface) will allow us to see if C3 grasses were already present on the landscape before 10 Ma.

However, Bovidae (cloven-hoofed, ruminants like buffalo and antelopes) similarly track this large-scale environmental opening of environments over the course of the THS, as mesowear (macroscopic tooth wear analysis) and stable carbon isotopic data demonstrate that their dietary ecology diversified from being C3 (browse) dominated in the middle Miocene, to comprising browsing, grazing, and mixed feeding after the late Miocene and into the present (Figure 3.). Bovid tribes often maintained discreet dietary ecologies, with Alcelaphini (wildebeest) and Aepycerotini (impala) plotting as obligate grazers, and Tragelaphini (kudu and eland) plotting as browsing dominated mixed feeders. Mesowear and stable carbon isotopic data from the THS also show, for the first time, that mesowear and isotopic data describe comparable paleodietary behaviors when mesowear is more ‘generally’ scored (such as when teeth are described as having a browsing, grazing, or mixed feeding signal) rather than when it is more ‘specifically’ scored (such as when feeding categories for browsing-dominated, and grazing dominated, mixed feeding are included).

Finally, data from the Plio-Pleistocene component of the THS (5.3-1.8 Ma) demonstrate that fossil sites track eccentricity, or the shape of Earth’s orbit (Figure 4.). On periodicities of 100,000 years, Earth’s orbit cycles between being circular and elliptical, and this in turn moderates terrestrial effects such as the cycling of lakes and rivers on a landscape. In the THS, fossil sites occur when eccentricity is low, and the basin’s ancestral lake margin is recessed, likely because the appropriate depositional environments for fossil formation were present. While there are distinct stable carbon and oxygen isotopic signatures that occur between sites, these are still under evaluation, and current questions relate to if these dietary signatures relate to differences in lake margin fluctuation on the order of 23,000 years. Ultimately, this level of ‘refined’ data will help us determine the degree of heterogeneity present in hominin environments, and how much heterogeneity previously seen in the fossil record is due to temporal and spatial averaging.
